content: needs to be stretchy if the socks are intended to be worn i would always recommend a long tail cast on or its variant the twisted german cast on but feel free to use your personal favourite if you have one if you are planning to work the leg of the sock fairly long and/or if your calves are significantly more pronounced in relation to your ankles or for people with circulation issues in their legs it can be a good idea to work the cuff with more sts than you would need for the leg and then reduce them once you start with the plain leg section this will result in a less grippy cuff that may be more prone to sagging though if in doubt work the cuff and try it on worst-case scenario you may have to re-start with a different stitch count but that s a small effort to achieve a well-fitting pair of socks the cuff is generally worked in rib whether you pick a k1 p1 or a k2 p2 rib or anything else you may fancy is a matter of personal choice i tend to default to 2x2 rib as it looks neater than 1x1 but do what works best for you a rib needs a certain amount of length to fully function i would not go shorter than 10 rounds at the very least and my standard length is 24 rounds for a 64 st sock there is another option to work a hem with or without picot at the cuff but this is traditionally more common on knee length stockings you will need to run a piece of elastic inside the tube of the hem to make the stockings stay up and the construction is fairly elaborate so for now let s stick with the classic rib cast on 64 sts and close to a round taking care not to twist the cast on round 1 k2 p2 to end repeat round 1 for a total of 24 rounds sock page 3 leg if you have worked your cuff with a higher stitch count k 1 round in which you decrease the surplus sts evenly to bring you back to the number needed if you have worked the cuff with the correct number to start with you are good to proceed imme- diately knit as many rounds as desired to give you the required leg length on longer stockings you would need to work a shaping for the calves but on a standard sock the leg is just worked as a straight tube without increases or decreases this is really the easiest part of the sock and this is where most of the patterning would happen if you were to work a sock in a lace cable or colour work design the leg can be worked as long as you fancy within reason obviously - i personally like my socks longer and would normally work around 60 64 rounds for the
